insights.description: Percentage of responses with status code 2xx

alerts.name: Absence of Anti-CSRF Tokens
alerts.desc:
No Anti-CSRF tokens were found in a HTML submission form.

A cross-site request forgery is an attack that involves forcing a victim to send an HTTP request to a target destination without their knowledge or intent in order to perform an action as the victim. The underlying cause is application functionality using predictable URL/form actions in a repeatable way. The nature of the attack is that CSRF exploits the trust that a web site has for a user. By contrast, cross-site scripting (XSS) exploits the trust that a user has for a web site. Like XSS, CSRF attacks are not necessarily cross-site, but they can be. Cross-site request forgery is also known as CSRF, XSRF, one-click attack, session riding, confused deputy, and sea surf.

CSRF attacks are effective in a number of situations, including:

* The victim has an active session on the target site.

* The victim is authenticated via HTTP auth on the target site.

* The victim is on the same local network as the target site.

CSRF has primarily been used to perform an action against a target site using the victim's privileges, but recent techniques have been discovered to disclose information by gaining access to the response. The risk of information disclosure is dramatically increased when the target site is vulnerable to XSS, because XSS can be used as a platform for CSRF, allowing the attack to operate within the bounds of the same-origin policy.

instances.otherinfo: No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token, _csrfToken] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 1: "jcrMethodToCall" "search" "src_languages.values" "src_originSiteKey" "src_sites.values" "src_sitesForReferences.values" "src_terms[0].applyFilter" "src_terms[0].fields.files" "src_terms[0].fields.siteContent" "src_terms[0].fields.tags" "src_terms[0].match" ].

alerts.solution:
Phase: Architecture and Design

Use a vetted library or framework that does not allow this weakness to occur or provides constructs that make this weakness easier to avoid.

For example, use anti-CSRF packages such as the OWASP CSRFGuard.

Phase: Implementation

Ensure that your application is free of cross-site scripting issues, because most CSRF defenses can be bypassed using attacker-controlled script.

Phase: Architecture and Design

Generate a unique nonce for each form, place the nonce into the form, and verify the nonce upon receipt of the form. Be sure that the nonce is not predictable (CWE-330).

Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

Identify especially dangerous operations. When the user performs a dangerous operation, send a separate confirmation request to ensure that the user intended to perform that operation.

Note that this can be bypassed using XSS.

Use the ESAPI Session Management control.

This control includes a component for CSRF.

Do not use the GET method for any request that triggers a state change.

Phase: Implementation

Check the HTTP Referer header to see if the request originated from an expected page. This could break legitimate functionality, because users or proxies may have disabled sending the Referer for privacy reasons.
alerts.otherinfo: No known Anti-CSRF token [anticsrf, CSRFToken, __RequestVerificationToken, csrfmiddlewaretoken, authenticity_token, OWASP_CSRFTOKEN, anoncsrf, csrf_token, _csrf, _csrfSecret, __csrf_magic, CSRF, _token, _csrf_token, _csrfToken] was found in the following HTML form: [Form 1: "jcrMethodToCall" "search" "src_languages.values" "src_originSiteKey" "src_sites.values" "src_sitesForReferences.values" "src_terms[0].applyFilter" "src_terms[0].fields.files" "src_terms[0].fields.siteContent" "src_terms[0].fields.tags" "src_terms[0].match" ].

alerts.alert: CSP: Failure to Define Directive with No Fallback
alerts.name: CSP: Failure to Define Directive with No Fallback
alerts.desc: The Content Security Policy fails to define one of the directives that has no fallback. Missing/excluding them is the same as allowing anything.

instances.evidence: default-src 'self' blob: *.urssaf.fr voxusagers.numerique.gouv.fr *.dailymotion.com *.google-analytics.com *.hcaptcha.com *.net-entreprises.fr *.youtube.com *.google.com *.gstatic.com *.facebook.net 'unsafe-inline' data: *.tagcommander.com *.commander1.com *.trustcommander.net *.googleapis.com *.staging.k8s.recouv cdn-virtual-agent-enriched.smartly.ai apis-virtual-agent-enriched.smartly.ai webchat-virtual-agent-enriched.smartly.ai smartly-image-stage.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com media-virtual-agent-enriched.smartly.ai cdnjs.cloudflare.com production-rogeraccess-webapp.rogervoice.com *.amazonaws.com *.abtasty.com *.doyoudreamup.com *.dydu.ai *.cobrowse.io wss:; script-src 'self' blob: *.youtube.com tag.aticdn.net *.urssaf.fr *.google-analytics.com *.google.com *.gstatic.com *.net-entreprises.fr 'unsafe-eval' 'unsafe-inline' *.tagcommander.com *.trustcommander.net *.commander1.com cdn-virtual-agent-enriched.smartly.ai cdnjs.cloudflare.com cdn.polyfill.io webrtc.github.io widget.rogervoice.com production-rogeraccess.rogervoice.com production-rogeraccess-webapp.rogervoice.com *.staging.k8s.recouv *.googleapis.com *.abtasty.com *.mouseflow.com *.doyoudreamup.com *.dydu.ai *.cobrowse.io
instances.otherinfo: The directive(s): frame-ancestors, form-action is/are among the directives that do not fallback to default-src.

alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is properly configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.
alerts.otherinfo: The directive(s): frame-ancestors, form-action is/are among the directives that do not fallback to default-src.

alerts.name: CSP: Wildcard Directive
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks. Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

instances.otherinfo:
The following directives either allow wildcard sources (or ancestors), are not defined, or are overly broadly defined:
style-src, img-src, connect-src, frame-src, font-src, media-src, object-src, manifest-src

alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is properly configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.

style-src, img-src, connect-src, frame-src, font-src, media-src, object-src, manifest-src

Including (but not limited to) Cross Site Scripting (XSS), and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.

alerts.name: Missing Anti-clickjacking Header
alerts.desc: The response does not protect against 'ClickJacking' attacks. It should include either Content-Security-Policy with 'frame-ancestors' directive or X-Frame-Options.
alerts.solution:
Modern Web browsers support the Content-Security-Policy and X-Frame-Options HTTP headers. Ensure one of them is set on all web pages returned by your site/app.

If you expect the page to be framed only by pages on your server (e.g. it's part of a FRAMESET) then you'll want to use SAMEORIGIN, otherwise if you never expect the page to be framed, you should use DENY. Alternatively consider implementing Content Security Policy's "frame-ancestors" directive.

alerts.name: Sub Resource Integrity Attribute Missing
alerts.desc: The integrity attribute is missing on a script or link tag served by an external server. The integrity tag prevents an attacker who have gained access to this server from injecting a malicious content.
alerts.solution: Provide a valid integrity attribute to the tag.

alerts.name: Cookie No HttpOnly Flag
alerts.desc: A cookie has been set without the HttpOnly flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed by JavaScript. If a malicious script can be run on this page then the cookie will be accessible and can be transmitted to another site. If this is a session cookie then session hijacking may be possible.
alerts.solution: Ensure that the HttpOnly flag is set for all cookies.

alerts.name: Cookie Without Secure Flag
alerts.desc: A cookie has been set without the secure flag, which means that the cookie can be accessed via unencrypted connections.
alerts.solution: Whenever a cookie contains sensitive information or is a session token, then it should always be passed using an encrypted channel. Ensure that the secure flag is set for cookies containing such sensitive information.

alerts.name: Cookie without SameSite Attribute
alerts.desc: A cookie has been set without the SameSite attribute, which means that the cookie can be sent as a result of a 'cross-site' request. The SameSite attribute is an effective counter measure to cross-site request forgery, cross-site script inclusion, and timing attacks.
alerts.solution: Ensure that the SameSite attribute is set to either 'lax' or ideally 'strict' for all cookies.

alerts.name: Cross-Domain JavaScript Source File Inclusion
alerts.desc: The page includes one or more script files from a third-party domain.
alerts.solution: Ensure JavaScript source files are loaded from only trusted sources, and the sources can't be controlled by end users of the application.

alerts.alert: Insufficient Site Isolation Against Spectre Vulnerability
alerts.name: Insufficient Site Isolation Against Spectre Vulnerability
alerts.desc: Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy header is an opt-in header designed to counter side-channels attacks like Spectre. Resource should be specifically set as shareable amongst different origins.
alerts.solution:
Ensure that the application/web server sets the Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy header appropriately, and that it sets the Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy header to 'same-origin' for all web pages.

'same-site' is considered as less secured and should be avoided.

If resources must be shared, set the header to 'cross-origin'.

If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that supports the Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy header (https://caniuse.com/mdn-http_headers_cross-origin-resource-policy).

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Permissions-Policy header.

alerts.name: Base64 Disclosure
alerts.desc: Base64 encoded data was disclosed by the application/web server. Note: in the interests of performance not all base64 strings in the response were analyzed individually, the entire response should be looked at by the analyst/security team/developer(s).
alerts.solution: Manually confirm that the Base64 data does not leak sensitive information, and that the data cannot be aggregated/used to exploit other vulnerabilities.

alerts.name: Modern Web Application
alerts.desc: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.

instances.otherinfo: Links have been found that do not have traditional href attributes, which is an indication that this is a modern web application.

alerts.solution: This is an informational alert and so no changes are required.
alerts.otherinfo: Links have been found that do not have traditional href attributes, which is an indication that this is a modern web application.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.
alerts.solution: Ensure that Sec-Fetch-Dest header is included in request headers.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.
alerts.solution: Ensure that Sec-Fetch-Mode header is included in request headers.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.
alerts.solution: Ensure that Sec-Fetch-Site header is included in request headers.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.
alerts.solution: Ensure that Sec-Fetch-User header is included in user initiated requests.

alerts.name: Session Management Response Identified
alerts.desc: The given response has been identified as containing a session management token. The 'Other Info' field contains a set of header tokens that can be used in the Header Based Session Management Method. If the request is in a context which has a Session Management Method set to "Auto-Detect" then this rule will change the session management to use the tokens identified.
alerts.solution: This is an informational alert rather than a vulnerability and so there is nothing to fix.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

instances.otherinfo: In the absence of an explicitly specified caching lifetime directive in the response, a liberal lifetime heuristic of 1 year was assumed. This is permitted by rfc7234.

alerts.solution:
Validate that the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information. If it does, consider the use of the following HTTP response headers, to limit, or prevent the content being stored and retrieved from the cache by another user:

Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private

Pragma: no-cache

Expires: 0

This configuration directs both HTTP 1.0 and HTTP 1.1 compliant caching servers to not store the response, and to not retrieve the response (without validation) from the cache, in response to a similar request.
alerts.otherinfo: In the absence of an explicitly specified caching lifetime directive in the response, a liberal lifetime heuristic of 1 year was assumed. This is permitted by rfc7234.
